ratings.question_text: Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
comments: office hours!
N/A

I thought Madame Burton did a fantastic job teaching our course this semester, especially given the special circumstances of this year. I thought she was especially effective at providing a mix of lecture, discussion, and the use of break-out groups to really give our class lots of exposure to French.

narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: A better understanding of the french language and more confidence in speaking.
I expanded my skills in listening and reading material in French significantly. I also gained knowledge of certain French texts and films.
Improved my French reading, writing, and speaking skills.  Also gained exposure to notable French authors and film directors.
I learned many things but I better understood pronunciation (discriminating bw similar-sounding words) and when to use certain tenses
Building upon basic French knowledge and increased speaking skills.

I learned about new conjugation modes in French, and different ways in which they can be combined to create a wide variety of expressions (e.g., pres. + future, conditionelle + future, etc.). I also greatly improved my vocabulary and ability to understand written passages of French through reading the required texts.
Grammar skills, vocabulary

My knowledge of French, and my confidence in speaking/reading French, really went up this semester. I feel like I have a much stronger grasp of French grammar, have expanded my vocabulary, and now feel more comfortable reading and discussing complex French texts.

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: For an online course, it wasn't bad at all.

Strengths: We had a lot of practice (everyday) with oral production and comprehension.
Weaknesses: The audio recordings felt often tedious and in need of update so that it is easier to move forwards and backwards within one.

Strengths: Very well structured course that follows a clear path. Each unit of learning builds upon the last and broadens one's grammatical and speaking skills. Professor Burton was absolutely excellent. Of all my professors, she has been the most engaging and impressive over the Zoom platform. 

Weaknesses: For a graduate student, there is a lot of work required for this course. Meeting each day and requiring homework to be completed in advance of each course was challenging. Were this class to be less demanding, I likely would pursue the next level of the undergraduate French track.
Maybe there could be more writing opportunities to enhance essay skills. A strength was how students were able to have conversations in breakout rooms to practice conversational French
In my opinion, one of the most useful French classes. It takes the material learned in L1 and 2 and gives easier ways to learn and speak the language. Intense, but great experience.

The course is organized in a manner in which each unity incorporates aspects of the previous unit while also adding new material; this allows us to retain past lessons while still being able to plow ahead in our learning of French. The tests are fair and reflect the work that we do on a daily basis.
Strengths - Mme. Burton is the best, there are a lot of ways to earn credit, great reading/source material

This is my third semester taking French at Yale, and I am continually impressed with the high-level of instruction provided by the department.  I feel like I am learning the language much more quickly than I expected, which is a pleasant surprise! This past semester, I thought the biggest strength of the course was the material.  All the books we read and films we watched were genuinely interesting to discuss, and were a great challenge for my French.  Additionally, this course's clear emphasis on oral production was great. Every class, Madame would use the breakout room function on Zoom to really force everyone to practice their speaking.  My favorite assignment was our presentation we had to give this semester. Everyone was allowed to pick their own topic connected to the francophone world. What was so great about this, was it allowed me to acquire new vocabulary words specifically relevant to my areas of interest.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: The breakout rooms for speaking practice was a hit!
This class was really good with virtual because we were able to speak often in breakout rooms.

Excellent course engagement over Zoom. The use of breakout rooms was perfect to encourage speaking amongst students. As noted above, Professor Burton's use of Zoom was the best I have seen from any Yale professor.
It was good. I think that being able to utilize breakout rooms so quickly and efficiently was a big improvement over in person French.
Everything went as well as possible
I thought all aspects of the course worked pretty well virtually; homework was equally as engaging as my previous French classes and the tests were administered without too much technical hiccup.
successes - owl testing, break out rooms

I was really impressed with Madame's ability to keep our course engaging and effective despite its unorthodox format.  Again, the use of the breakout rooms to facilitate constant discussion was a great way to take advantage of Zoom.  One small improvement I would suggest for next semester relates to the final exam -- rather than conduct the final on a Microsoft Word document, I think it would have been better to conduct the exam via the OWL system like all the other tests.  The Word doc was a bit clunky and distracting given that its format would keep shifting as you typed.  Additionally, it was a little strange to have to get used to the new format after having become used to the OWL model this semester.

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Definitely! Every assignment and reading was actually helpful. Nothing felt like busy work. I never questioned why am I learning a concept. Each book was a page turner and the films helped bring things full circle.
Yes, if you're looking to get a better grasp of grammar and use of the French language. It is a very high workload, but by the end so worth it.
Yes, I would absolutely recommend this course. Through this course, I improved my French reading, writing, and speaking skills.  Also gained exposure to notable French authors and film directors.
If you're actually interested in French, definitely
Yes! The course helps you appreciate French culture as well as enhancing students skills
Yes.
Yes, but on the caveat that it is quite a large commitment. I would only recommend it to students with a legitimate desire to learn more about French culture and history.
absolutely - especially with Mme. Burton !

I would definitely recommend this course to a student.  Yale's French program is fantastic, especially if you're trying to acquire a working proficiency in the language as quickly as possible. However, I would warn them that there is a fair amount of work required for the course, which could be a challenge if they're already taking a heavy course load.  But of course, continuous practice and repetition is required for language learning, so that should be expected.
